title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
In programming, syntax refers to the set of rules that define the combinations of symbols considered correctly structured programs in a given language. In simpler terms, it‚Äôs the specific way you must write your instructions so that the R interpreter can understand and execute them.
Understanding R syntax is absolutely crucial because even a tiny mistake‚Äîa missing comma, a misplaced parenthesis, or incorrect capitalisation‚Äîcan lead to errors that prevent your code from running. Mastering these basics empowers you to write clean, efficient, and error-free scripts, laying a solid foundation for your data journey.

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
In programming, syntax refers to the set of rules that define the combinations of symbols considered correctly structured programs in a given language. In simpler terms, it‚Äôs the specific way you must write your instructions so that the R interpreter can understand and execute them.
Understanding R syntax is absolutely crucial because even a tiny mistake‚Äîa missing comma, a misplaced parenthesis, or incorrect capitalisation‚Äîcan lead to errors that prevent your code from running. Mastering these basics empowers you to write clean, efficient, and error-free scripts, laying a solid foundation for your data journey.

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
section: R Syntax Basics: Your First Steps in Coding
text:
R Syntax Basics: Your First Steps in Coding
Let‚Äôs dive into the core elements of R syntax that you‚Äôll encounter every day.

Comments: The Programmer‚Äôs Notes
Comments are lines in your code that R ignores. They are incredibly useful for you and others to understand what your code does, why you made certain choices, or to temporarily disable a line of code.
In R, you use the hash symbol # to indicate a comment.

Anything after # on a line is treated as a comment.

Comments improve code readability and maintainability.


# This is a single-line comment
x <- 10 # This comment explains what x is



Variables and Assignment: Storing Your Data
Variables are like named containers that hold values. You use them to store data (numbers, text, logical values) so you can refer to it and manipulate it later in your script. In R, the primary way to assign a value to a variable is using the assignment operator <- (a less-than sign followed by a hyphen).

You can also use = for assignment, but <- is generally preferred for clarity and consistency in R.
Variable names should start with a letter and can contain letters, numbers, and underscores (_) or periods (.).
R is case-sensitive! myVariable is different from myvariable.


# Assigning a number to a variable
my_number <- 42

# Assigning text (a character string)
my_text <- "Hello, R!"

# Assigning a logical value
is_active <- TRUE



Data Types: What Kind of Information Are You Handling?
Every piece of data in R has a type, which tells R what kind of information it is and how it can be used. Understanding data types is fundamental for performing correct operations.

Numeric: For numbers (integers like 5 or decimals like 3.14).
Character: For text, enclosed in single or double quotes ("hello", 'world').
Logical: For boolean values, either TRUE or FALSE.


# Numeric examples
age <- 30
pi_value <- 3.14159

# Character examples
name <- "Alice"
message <- 'Welcome to R programming.'

# Logical examples
is_raining <- FALSE
has_data <- TRUE

# You can check the type with the class() function
class(age)

[1] "numeric"

class(name)

[1] "character"




Vectors: The Building Blocks of R
Vectors are the most basic data structure in R. They are ordered collections of elements of the same data type. You create vectors using the c() function, which stands for ‚Äúcombine‚Äù or ‚Äúconcatenate‚Äù.

All elements in a vector must be of the same type (numeric, character, or logical).
Vectors can be of any length, from a single element to thousands.


# A numeric vector
ages <- c(25, 30, 35, 40)

# A character vector
names <- c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie")

# A logical vector
results <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, TRUE)

# Accessing elements in a vector (R uses 1-based indexing!)
ages[1] # Returns 25

[1] 25

names[3] # Returns "Charlie"

[1] "Charlie"

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
section: R Code Structure: How R Organizes Instructions
text:
R Code Structure: How R Organizes Instructions
Beyond individual syntax elements, understanding how R structures sequences of instructions is key to writing functional scripts.

Functions: Performing Actions
Functions are pre-defined blocks of code that perform a specific task. They take inputs (called arguments) and often return an output. You call a function by writing its name followed by parentheses, inside which you pass any required arguments.

Common functions include print(), sum(), mean(), sqrt().
Arguments are passed inside the parentheses, separated by commas.


# Using the print() function to display output
print("Hello, world!")

[1] "Hello, world!"

# Using the sum() function on a vector
numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
total <- sum(numbers)
print(total) # Output: 15

[1] 15

# Using the mean() function
average <- mean(numbers)
print(average) # Output: 3

[1] 3




Operators: Doing Math and Comparisons
Operators are special symbols that perform operations on values and variables. R has a rich set of operators for arithmetic, comparison, and logical operations.

Arithmetic: + (addition), - (subtraction), * (multiplication), / (division), ^ or ** (exponentiation), %% (modulo ‚Äì remainder), %/% (integer division).
Relational (Comparison): == (equal to), != (not equal to), < (less than), > (greater than), <= (less than or equal to), >= (greater than or equal to). These return logical (TRUE/FALSE) values.
Logical: & (AND), | (OR), ! (NOT). Used to combine or negate logical conditions.


# Arithmetic examples
result_add <- 5 + 3
result_mult <- 4 * 2
result_pow <- 2^3 # 8

# Relational examples
is_equal <- (10 == 10) # TRUE
is_greater <- (7 > 12) # FALSE

# Logical examples
condition1 <- TRUE
condition2 <- FALSE
combined_and <- condition1 & condition2 # FALSE
combined_or <- condition1 | condition2 # TRUE
not_condition1 <- !condition1 # FALSE



Control Flow: Making Decisions (If/Else)
Control flow statements allow your code to make decisions or repeat actions based on certain conditions. The most fundamental control flow structure is the if statement, often paired with else.

An if statement executes a block of code only if a specified condition is TRUE.
An else block provides an alternative action if the if condition is FALSE.
Code blocks are typically enclosed in curly braces {}.


score <- 75

if (score >= 60) {
 print("You passed!")
} else {
 print("You need to study more.")
}

[1] "You passed!"

# You can also have "else if" for multiple conditions
grade <- "B"

if (grade == "A") {
 print("Excellent!")
} else if (grade == "B") {
 print("Good job!")
} else {
 print("Keep practicing.")
}

[1] "Good job!"

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
section: Common R Syntax Pitfalls for Beginners
text:
Common R Syntax Pitfalls for Beginners
Even experienced programmers make syntax errors. Here are a few common ones to watch out for as you learn R code structure:

Case Sensitivity: Remember, variable is not the same as Variable. This applies to function names too!
Missing Parentheses or Brackets: A common oversight, especially with nested functions or vector indexing. R will often tell you it‚Äùs expecting something.
Incorrect Assignment vs.¬†Equality: Using = when you mean == (or vice versa) can lead to unexpected results or errors.
Quotation Marks: For character strings, always use matching single or double quotes (e.g., "text" or 'text', not "text').
Object Not Found: This usually means you‚Äùve misspelled a variable name, forgotten to assign a value, or haven‚Äùt loaded a necessary package.

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
What Are Variables in R?
At its core, a variable in R is a symbolic name that refers to a value. This value could be a single number, a piece of text, a logical true/false statement, or even a complex data structure like a dataset. When you assign a value to a variable, R stores that value in memory and associates it with the name you‚Äùve chosen.
Why are they so important? Variables allow you to reuse data without retyping it, make your code dynamic (data can change without changing the code itself), and greatly improve the readability of your scripts. Instead of a ‚Äúmagic number,‚Äù you can have a variable named "tax_rate".

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
The Primary Assignment Operator: <-
In R, the most common and recommended way to assign a value to a variable is by using the assignment operator <-. This operator is often referred to as the ‚Äúgets‚Äù operator because you can read it as ‚Äúvariable gets value.‚Äù The value on the right-hand side is ‚Äúassigned to‚Äù or ‚Äúgets‚Äù stored in the variable on the left-hand side.

Basic Assignment with <-
Let‚Äùs start with a simple example. We‚Äùll assign the number 10 to a variable named my_number.

my_number <- 10
print(my_number)

[1] 10


When you run this code, R creates a variable called my_number and stores the value 10 inside it. The print() function then displays the value of that variable.


Assigning Different Data Types
R is a dynamically typed language, meaning you don‚Äùt need to declare the data type of a variable before assigning a value. R automatically infers the type based on the value you assign. You can assign various types of data to variables using <-:

Numeric: For numbers (integers, decimals).
Character: For text (strings).
Logical: For TRUE/FALSE values.


# Assigning a numeric value (decimal)
price <- 29.99
print(price)

[1] 29.99

# Assigning a character (string) value
product_name <- "R Programming Guide"
print(product_name)

[1] "R Programming Guide"

# Assigning a logical (boolean) value
is_available <- TRUE
print(is_available)

[1] TRUE

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
Naming Conventions for Variables
Choosing good names for your variables is just as important as knowing how to assign them. Clear, descriptive names make your code much more understandable for yourself and others. Here are some key guidelines for naming variables in R:

Start with a letter or a dot: Variable names cannot start with a number. If they start with a dot, the next character must be a letter.
No spaces: Use underscores (_) or periods (.) to separate words, or use camel case.
No special characters: Avoid symbols like @, #, $, %, ^, &, *, (, ), -, +, =, ~, !.
Be descriptive: total_sales is much better than ts.
Be consistent: If you use snake_case (e.g., my_variable), stick to it throughout your project. Other common styles include camelCase (e.g., myVariable) and dot.case (e.g., my.variable).
Avoid reserved words: Don‚Äùt use names that R already uses, such as if, else, for, function, TRUE, FALSE, NA, NULL.


# Good variable names
user_age <- 30
first.name <- "Alice"
totalRevenue <- 1500.75

# Bad variable names (will cause errors or confusion)
1st_quarter <- 100 # Starts with a number
my variable <- "data" # Contains a space
sum <- 5 # "sum" is a built-in function

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
Entering Data
For small data sets, you can enter data directly into vectors (also known as columns).

heights <- c(62, 70, 59, 65, 68)
heights

[1] 62 70 59 65 68

## [1] 62 70 59 65 68

The first line of the syntax creates a new variable named¬†heights¬†with five data points.
The second line prints the contents of¬†heights¬†to the output window.

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
Reading Data from Files
For larger data sets, you can save the data into a separate¬†text file, which can be¬†comma-¬†or¬†tab-delimited. For example, the following command reads in a CSV file and stores the contents into a new R object called¬†data:

data <- read.csv("FILENAME")

If you type:

data <- read.csv("FILENAME", header = TRUE)

the¬†first row¬†will be used as names for each column.
Otherwise, if you use:

data <- read.csv("FILENAME")

you‚Äôll need to manually add column names later using:

names(data) <- c("VAR1", "VAR2", "VAR3")

Here,¬†VAR1¬†corresponds to the first variable name, and so on.
Make sure there are as many names as there are columns in the object¬†data.

title: R Basics: Syntax & Variables
text:
File Paths and Working Directory
FILENAME¬†is a file that resides in the¬†current working directory.
If the file is located elsewhere, you need to specify the¬†full file path¬†so R can find it, for example:

read.csv("C:\\working\\data\\FILENAME.csv")

On¬†Windows, you can use either¬†double backslashes (\\)¬†or¬†single forward slashes (/), e.g.:

read.csv("C:/rich/working/data/FILENAME.csv")

On¬†Mac¬†and¬†Linux, the¬†forward slash (/)¬†format is the only one that works:

read.csv("/Users/username/Documents/data/FILENAME.csv")


Summary

Use¬†c()¬†to enter small datasets directly into vectors.
Use¬†read.csv()¬†to load larger datasets from files.
Always check your¬†working directory¬†and use correct file path formatting for your operating system.
If¬†header = TRUE, the first row of your file will automatically become column names.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
The MSDA course website is collaboratively developed by the teaching team using Quarto and GitHub Desktop.
Each instructor is responsible for maintaining their own content section, while the course coordinator publishes the overall site to GitHub Pages.
Teachers may freely edit and render locally, but only the coordinator handles the final public build.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
The MSDA course website is collaboratively developed by the teaching team using Quarto and GitHub Desktop.
Each instructor is responsible for maintaining their own content section, while the course coordinator publishes the overall site to GitHub Pages.
Teachers may freely edit and render locally, but only the coordinator handles the final public build.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
2 Folder Structure
Below is the structure of the shared repository:
MSDA-course/ 

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Content/ 
‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Math/             ‚Üê Maths lectures (Josh) 
‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Stats/            ‚Üê Statistics lectures (Javiera) 
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Tutorials/ 
‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Math/             ‚Üê Maths tutorials
‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Stats/            ‚Üê Stats tutorials
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ assets/                 ‚Üê shared images, datasets, CSS 
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                   ‚Üê published site output (auto-generated) 
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ styles.css
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ edtheme.scss 
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ_quarto.yml

Do¬†not¬†edit the¬†docs/¬†folder manually; it‚Äôs created by Quarto.
Shared styles (styles.css,¬†edtheme.scss) live at the project root.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
3 Working Locally

Clone the repository in GitHub Desktop ‚Üí¬†File ‚Üí Clone Repository.
Open the project in RStudio by double-clicking the¬†.Rproj¬†file.
Edit only your section:

Josh ‚Üí¬†Content/Math/,¬†Tutorials/Math/
Javiera ‚Üí¬†Content/Stats/,¬†Tutorials/Stats/

Preview locally using:

quarto preview
‚Ä¶or press the¬†Render¬†button in RStudio. This builds a local preview only (not the live site).

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
4 Keep Pages Hidden with¬†draft
When a page is in progress, add the YAML header below at the top of the¬†.qmd:
---
title: "Week X ‚Äì Title"
draft: true
---
Draft pages render locally but are¬†not¬†published.

When ready to release, switch to:

---
title: "Week X ‚Äì Title"
draft: false
---

(or remove¬†draft:¬†entirely).

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
5 Weekly Release Workflow
We publish¬†one week at a time:

Finalise the week‚Äôs¬†.qmd¬†files; remove¬†draft: true.
Notify the¬†course coordinator¬†(currently Javiera).
Coordinator updates¬†_quarto.yml¬†if using selective rendering and runs:

    quarto render

Coordinator commits and pushes the updated¬†docs/¬†folder so GitHub Pages updates.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
6 Version Control (GitHub Desktop)

Before editing:¬†Fetch origin ‚Üí Pull.
After editing:

Review changed files.
Write a clear message (e.g.,¬†Add Week 3 tutorial draft).
Commit to main.
Push origin.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
7 Roles & Permissions

Teachers have¬†write access¬†and may edit and render locally¬†only¬†in their area.
The¬†course coordinator¬†performs the project-wide render and publishes the site (pushes¬†docs/).
Avoid editing others‚Äô folders to reduce merge conflicts.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
8 Selective Rendering (publish only chosen weeks)
Coordinator whitelists what gets built in¬†_quarto.yml:
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: docs
  render:
    - index.qmd
    - Content/Math/week-01.qmd
    - Tutorials/Math/week-01.qmd
    - Content/Stats/week-01.qmd
    - Tutorials/Stats/week-01.qmd
    # Add further weeks here as they are approved
Anything¬†not¬†listed under¬†render:¬†is skipped, even if it is not a draft.

title: Teacher Guidelines ‚Äì MSDA Course Website
text:
9 Section Styling (Math vs Stats)
Use folder-level¬†_metadata.yml¬†files so each area can have its own CSS.
Content/Math/_metadata.yml
format:
  html:
    css: [styles.css, edtheme.scss]   # site base + Maths overrides
Tutorials/Math/_metadata.yml

format:
  html:
    css: [styles.css, edtheme.scss]   # site base + Maths overrides
Content/Stats/_metadata.yml

format:
  html:
    css: styles.css
Tutorials/Stats/_metadata.yml

format:
  html:
    css: styles.css
Keep¬†styles.css¬†and¬†edtheme.scss¬†at the¬†project root.

title: Exponentials & Logs
text: These problems look at exponentials and logs, exploring how they‚Äôre used to model various real-world phenomena. You‚Äôll need a scientific calculator and a graphing tool like Geogebra or Desmos.

title: Exponentials & Logs
text:
1 Calculations
These questions review how exponentials and logarithms are used in calculations and visualisations.

Use a scientific calculator to find \(2^{12}\) and \(e^5\).
Use a scientific calculator to find \(\log_{2}(512)\), \(\log_{10}(1000)\), and \(\log_{e}(2.7)\).
If \(3^x + 19 = 100\), what‚Äôs \(x\)?
Using Geogebra or Desmos, plot the graphs of \(y = e^x\) and \(y = \ln(x)\).

title: Exponentials & Logs
text:
2 Modelling
Within humanities and social sciences, our main interest in exponentials and logs is how they can be used to model complicated phenomena.

2.1 Continuous Interest
Given an initial investment \(Q\) with an interest rate of \(r\), the amount of money at time \(t\) can be found as \[
  P(t) = Q e^{rt}.
\] This is a type of compound interest.

If the initial investment was ¬£100, with a continuous interest rate of 1.7% applied daily, how much money would there be after 365 days?
Using a tool of your choice, plot \(y = P(x)\). What is the meaning of the \(y\)-intercept?
Plot \(y = P(x)\) with a logarithmic \(y\)-axis. What‚Äôs the gradient now?



2.2 Population Growth
Given an initial population size \(P_0\), a growth rate \(r\) per day, and a maximum feasible population size \(K\), the population on day \(t\) is modelled logistically as
\[
  P(t) = \frac{P_0 \cdot K}{P_0 + (K - P_0)e^{-rt}}.
\]

Plot this model for \(P_0 = 10\), \(K = 500\), and \(r = 0.5\).
What is the range of this model for a domain \(t\geq0\)?
What happens if we extend the domain to \(t < 0\)?



2.3 Sound
You may have heard of decibel as a measure of how ‚Äòloud‚Äô something is. You may even have seen a chart like the one below that compare different sounds.



Generator Decibel Comparison Chart, Tom Holland (2022), CC BY-SA 4.0.


What you might not known though is that decibels are a logarithmic scale, defined by the equation \[
  d = 10\log\left(\frac{p}{p_{0}}\right).
\] Here \(p\) is the intensity or power of the sound (measured in Watts), \(p_0\) is intensity of the faintest audible sound, and \(d\) is volume in decibels.
Using this equation with \(p_0 = 1\) Watt, create a version of the graphic above that uses power, rather than decibels, to measure the sound.

title: Differentiation
text: This week uses calculus to explore the properties different models. Once you‚Äôve worked out an answer, you should check it against a scientific calculator, algebra software, or graphing software.

title: Differentiation
text:
1 Derivatives
Before we look at applications, here are some starter questions to practice differentiating.

Find \(f'(x)\) when \(f(x) = x^2\), \(f(x) = 3\), and \(f(x) = x^3 + 3x^2 + 3x + 1\).
Use two different methods to show \(\frac{\text{d}}{\text{d}x}\big((x+a)(x-a)\big) = 2x\) for all \(a\in\mathbb{R}\).
Find \(\dot{x}\) when \(x = e^{2t}\), \(x = \sin(2t)\), and \(x = \tan(t)\).

title: Differentiation
text:
2 Model Interpretations
In workshop two we looked at a range of different models for real-world phenomena. For each of these, use software to find the derivative of the model with respect to the independent variable. Then, examine it graphically and describe the meaning of the derivative in context.

Compound interest, modelled by \(P(t) = Q e^{rt}\), where \(Q\) is the initial investment and \(r\) is the rate of interest.
Population growth, modelled by \(P(t) = \frac{P_0 \cdot K}{P_0 + (K - P_0)e^{-rt}}\), with initial population size \(P_0\), a growth rate \(r\) per day, and a maximum feasible population size \(K\).
Sound in decibels, modelled by \(d(p) = 10\log\left(\frac{p}{p_{0}}\right)\), where \(p_0\) is intensity of the faintest audible sound.

title: Differentiation
text:
3 Optimization
We discussed how one of the key applications of differentiation is to find the maximum or minimum value a model can take. These points happen when the gradient is zero.

What point is the minimum of \(f(x) = \frac{x(x+1)}{2}\)?
Does this minimum have meaning in the context of \(S_n\) from the last workshop?
Could this be used to make a better argument that \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n \neq -\frac{1}{12}\)?

title: Differentiation
text:
4 Classifying Derivatives
It‚Äôs not always so clear whether a critical point is a maximum, minimum, or an inflection. To check this we look at the second derivative: \(\frac{\text{d}^2}{\text{d}x^2}\), \(f''(x)\), or \(\ddot{x}\).
At a point \(x\) where \(f'(x) = 0\):

If \(f''(x) > 0\), then \(x\) is a local minimum,
If \(f''(x) < 0\), then \(x\) is a local maximum,
If \(f''(x) = 0\), more information is needed.

This is sometimes called the derivative test.

Verify that \((-0.5, -0.125)\) is a minimum of \(f(x) = \frac{x(x+1)}{2}\).
Classify the critical points of \(f(x) = x^3 + 3x^2 - 6x - 8\).
Find the time at which the population \(P(t)\) is changing fastest.







Hint



If \(f(x) = \frac{f_1(x)}{f_2(x)}\), when is \(f(x) = 0\)?

title: Probability
text: After a couple of theory questions that are related to this week‚Äôs content, this workshop has a few different more ‚Äòpractical‚Äô exercises. When you get to these, you‚Äôre welcome to work with other people to explore the problems, working toward a solution collaboratively.

title: Probability
text:
1 The 52 Card Pickup
A standard 52 card deck is split into four suits (spades ‚ô†, hearts ‚ô•, clubs ‚ô£, and diamonds ‚ô¶), with 13 cards for each suit (an Ace, nine numbered \(2\)-\(10\), plus three face cards: Jack, Queen, and King).



Piatnik Cards, Trainler (2009), CC BY 3.0 Unported.


Sometimes aces are treated as a \(1\). At other times they‚Äôre treated as the most valuable card (known as ‚Äòace high‚Äô), as suggested in the photo above.
To ‚Äòdraw‚Äô a card means to choose one at random. From this deck,

What‚Äôs the probability of drawing üÇ°, the ace of spaces?
What‚Äôs the probability of drawing a red card? (i.e. ‚ô¶ or ‚ô•)
What‚Äôs the probability of drawing a Jack? (i.e. üÇ´, üÇª, üÉõ, or üÉã)
What‚Äôs the probability of drawing a face card?

Sometimes, we might have some information about the card we‚Äôve drawn. This changes things! From the 52 card deck,

What‚Äôs the probability of drawing an ace, given I know the card is red?
What‚Äôs the probability that the face card I just drew is a Jack?

title: Probability
text:
2 Sans Remplacement
In a game, cards are usually drawn continuously rather than putting them back between each draw. For example, if I draw 2 cards from a 52 card deck these cards cannot be the same: they are drawn without replacement.1 Starting each time from a full 52 card deck,

If I draw an ace, what‚Äôs the probability that the next draw is an ace?
If I draw a Jack card, what‚Äôs the chance of the next being a face?
If I draw red (‚ô¶ or ‚ô•), what‚Äôs the probability the next is black (‚ô† or ‚ô£)?

There‚Äôs a whole family of card games (including Blackjack, Pontoon, and Vingt-Un) where players aim to obtain a hand that adds up to 21. In these games, any face card is usually treated as a ‚Äò10‚Äô and an ace may count as a ‚Äò1‚Äô or an ‚Äò11‚Äô as the player desires.

Starting from a clean deck, what is the probability tree for getting 21 in just two cards?

title: Probability
text:
3 Dice Games
Each of these exercises includes an experimental aspect. There‚Äôs a wee bit of theory involved in each, but you‚Äôll need a set of the dice described to have a proper go!

3.1 Standard dice‚Ä¶ twice!
You‚Äôll need at least three or four standard six-sided dice - abbreviated to D6. Generally, we abbreviate rolling \(n\) many \(m\)-sided dice by nDm.



W√ºrfel, Dietmar Rabich (2021), CC BY-SA 4.0.



Roll 1D6. How likely was the outcome?
Roll 2D6, taking the sum as the outcome. How likely was this?
What does the probability tree look like for summing 2D6?
What happens as the number of D6 increase to 3D6, 4D6, or beyond?



3.2 The house always wins
Probabilities can sometimes behave in unintuitive ways, e.g. the gambler‚Äôs fallacy. For this exercise you‚Äôll need a set of three nontransitive dice.



Nontransitive dice, Chris Martin (2008), üÖÆ.



If rolling the three dice, which is the highest?
In pairs, try the following game:

Player 1 picks their dice,
Player 2 picks their dice,
Both roll and the highest wins.

What‚Äôs the winning strategy for player 2?
How does this change if instead it‚Äôs two dice and the results are added?



3.3 DIY D6
Many highstreet clothing chains attach ‚Äòsize cubes‚Äô to hangers so that shoppers don‚Äôt have to find the label to check the size. However, these aren‚Äôt widely reused and generate a lot of plastic waste.



Clothing store downtown Boston, Kurt Kaiser (2018), CC0.


Growing up, I had the idea that these could be reused as D6 using the top as the 1, the bottom as the 6, and the four sides as 2-5. Was I correct? Could these be reused as fair D6?

title: Probability
text:
Footnotes


This is in contrast to dice: if I roll two dice, they can have the same outcome. We say that the outcomes are drawn with replacement.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
This guide will help you get set up with R and RStudio for the IFP statistics and data skills modules. Please work through it before or during the first lab.


You have two main ways of using R and RStudio.


For the MSDA tutorial sessions, you will use the university computers, which already have¬†R¬†and¬†RStudio¬†installed. You do¬†not¬†need to download or install anything yourself.



Sit at any available computer in the lab.
Log in using your¬†university email address¬†and¬†password.

This is the same login you use for Learn and Outlook, university email, and other campus systems.





Once you are logged in:

Click on the¬†Start Menu¬†(bottom left).
Type¬†RStudio¬†in the search bar.
Click the¬†RStudio¬†application when it appears.

RStudio will open and start an R session automatically.
You do not need to install or configure anything.




If you prefer to work on your own laptop, install R and then RStudio Desktop.

Install¬†R¬†from the official website:
https://cran.r-project.org/
Choose your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux) and follow the download and install instructions.
Install¬†RStudio Desktop¬†from:
https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Once installed, open¬†RStudio. It should automatically find your R installation.

You only need to install R and RStudio once. After that you just open RStudio.




It is good practice to keep all the files for a course in one project folder.

In your¬†Documents¬†(or another sensible location), create a new folder called e.g.¬†IFP_Stats.
Open RStudio.
In the top-right of RStudio, click¬†Project (None) > New Project‚Ä¶.
Choose¬†Existing Directory.
Click¬†Browse, select your new¬†IFP_Stats¬†folder, then click¬†Choose¬†(or¬†Open), and finally¬†Create Project.

You should now see the project name at the top-right of RStudio. Any files you create will live inside this folder.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
You have two main ways of using R and RStudio.


For the MSDA tutorial sessions, you will use the university computers, which already have¬†R¬†and¬†RStudio¬†installed. You do¬†not¬†need to download or install anything yourself.



Sit at any available computer in the lab.
Log in using your¬†university email address¬†and¬†password.

This is the same login you use for Learn and Outlook, university email, and other campus systems.





Once you are logged in:

Click on the¬†Start Menu¬†(bottom left).
Type¬†RStudio¬†in the search bar.
Click the¬†RStudio¬†application when it appears.

RStudio will open and start an R session automatically.
You do not need to install or configure anything.




If you prefer to work on your own laptop, install R and then RStudio Desktop.

Install¬†R¬†from the official website:
https://cran.r-project.org/
Choose your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux) and follow the download and install instructions.
Install¬†RStudio Desktop¬†from:
https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Once installed, open¬†RStudio. It should automatically find your R installation.

You only need to install R and RStudio once. After that you just open RStudio.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
It is good practice to keep all the files for a course in one project folder.

In your¬†Documents¬†(or another sensible location), create a new folder called e.g.¬†IFP_Stats.
Open RStudio.
In the top-right of RStudio, click¬†Project (None) > New Project‚Ä¶.
Choose¬†Existing Directory.
Click¬†Browse, select your new¬†IFP_Stats¬†folder, then click¬†Choose¬†(or¬†Open), and finally¬†Create Project.

You should now see the project name at the top-right of RStudio. Any files you create will live inside this folder.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
Everything you type in the¬†Console¬†is sent directly to¬†R. The rest of the interface helps you organise, edit, and visualise your work.

# Try your first R command
2 + 2

[1] 4


You should see:
[1] 4

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
3.1 Storing values in R‚Äôs memory
In R, you create and store values by assigning them to a name. The assignment operator is:
<-
This symbol is pronounced¬†‚Äúarrow‚Äù, and it tells R to store a value in a named object.
The general structure is:
[name] <- [value]
For Example:

x <- 5

This creates an object called¬†x¬†and stores the value¬†5¬†inside it.

Rules for naming objects
There are a few important rules to follow when choosing names in R.

1. No spaces
Names cannot contain spaces.

lucky_number <- 5    ‚úî
lucky number <- 5    ‚úò

(The spaces¬†around¬†<-¬†do not matter; only spaces¬†inside¬†the name are not allowed.)


2. Names must start with a letter
A name must begin with a letter, not a number.

lucky_number <- 5     ‚úî
1lucky_number <- 5    ‚úò



3. R is case sensitive
Capital letters matter.

lucky_number
Lucky_Number

These refer to¬†different¬†objects.


4. Some words cannot be used as names
R has a set of¬†reserved words¬†that already have a special meaning. These include:
if,¬†else,¬†for,¬†in,¬†TRUE,¬†FALSE,¬†NULL,¬†NA,¬†NaN,¬†function
You do not need to memorise these. If you accidentally try to use one, R will warn you.



Objects appear in the Environment pane
After running a line such as:

x <- 5

Here we have created an object called¬†x¬†with the value 5. You can now use¬†x¬†in later calculations. You should also see¬†xappear in the¬†Environment¬†pane.

Try using the stored¬†x:

x

[1] 5

x * 3

[1] 15

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
4.1 Creating an R script

Go to¬†File > New File > R Script.
In the new script window (top left), type:


x <- 210
y <- 15
x / y

[1] 14



Put your cursor on the first line and press:


Ctrl + Enter¬†(Windows)
Cmd + Enter¬†(macOS)

R sends that line to the Console and runs it, then moves your cursor to the next line. Press it again to run the next lines.

Now change¬†x¬†to another number and re-run the lines.

To save your script:

Click¬†File > Save.
Give it a sensible name, e.g.¬†week1_examples.R, and save it in your¬†IFP_Stats¬†project folder.

You should now see the file listed under the¬†Files¬†tab (bottom right).

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
4.2 A very simple plot
Add this line at the bottom of your script:

plot(1, 5)








Run it. A small plot should appear in the¬†Plots¬†tab.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
section: 5.1 Creating your first R Markdown file
text:
5.1 Creating your first R Markdown file

Go to¬†File > New File > R Markdown‚Ä¶.
In the pop-up:

Title: e.g.¬†IFP Intro Lab
Author: your name
Leave ‚ÄúHTML‚Äù as the default output for now.

Click¬†OK. RStudio creates a template document.

Delete everything¬†below¬†the first code chunk so you start with a mostly empty file.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
section: 5.2 Adding and running a code chunk
text:
5.2 Adding and running a code chunk
Insert a new R code chunk by either:

Clicking¬†Insert > R¬†at the top of the editor, or
Pressing¬†Ctrl + Alt + I¬†(Windows) or¬†Option + Cmd + I¬†(macOS).

Inside the grey chunk, type:

print("Hello from the IFP!")

[1] "Hello from the IFP!"


You can run the chunk in three ways:

Put the cursor on the first line and press¬†Ctrl/Cmd + Enter¬†repeatedly.
Click the small green play button at the top right of the chunk.
With the cursor inside the chunk, press¬†Cmd + Shift + Enter¬†(macOS) or¬†Ctrl + Shift + Enter¬†(Windows).

The output appears just under the chunk.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
section: 5.3 Loading packages in an R Markdown file
text:
5.3 Loading packages in an R Markdown file
At the top of your document, in the first code chunk, add:

# Packages used in this document
library(tidyverse)

‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5
‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.5.2     ‚úî tibble    3.3.0
‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1
‚úî purrr     1.1.0     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


This assumes you have installed the¬†tidyverse¬†package (see below). Any messages that appear under the chunk are fine; they are just information.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
5.4 Writing headings and text
Outside code chunks, you write text as usual. R Markdown uses the¬†# symbol¬†to create headings in the final document. For example:
# R code examples

In this section we will try some basic R commands.
Heading levels work as follows:

#¬†gives a main heading,
##¬†gives a subheading,
###¬†gives a smaller subheading, and so on.


Be aware that:

Inside code chunks,¬†#¬†creates an R¬†comment¬†that R will ignore.
Outside code chunks,¬†#¬†creates a¬†heading¬†in the report.


5.5 ‚ÄúSource‚Äù and ‚ÄúVisual‚Äù modes
RStudio provides two ways of editing an R Markdown document:

Source mode
This shows the raw Markdown file, including:

code chunks,
formatting symbols (e.g.¬†#,¬†**bold**,¬†*italics*),
and output-format instructions.

Use this mode when you want full control over your document.



Visual mode
This behaves more like a word processor:

You see headings, formatting, and lists as they will appear in the final document,
Code chunks are shown as blocks that you can edit without typing backticks.

Visual mode is easier for beginners, but Source mode is useful once you want more precision in formatting.
You can switch between them at any time using the¬†Source/Visual¬†toggle at the top left of the editor.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
6.1 Installing tidyverse
You only need to install a package¬†once per computer.
In the Console (not in an R Markdown chunk), type:

install.packages("<package name>")


install.packages("tidyverse")

and press¬†Enter. This will download and install the package. It may take a few minutes.
On some university servers tidyverse may already be installed. If so,¬†install.packages()¬†is not necessary there.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
6.2 Loading a package
Each time you start RStudio, you need to¬†load¬†any packages you want to use:

library(<package name>)


library(tidyverse)

You usually put these¬†library()¬†calls near the top of your script or R Markdown file so that anyone reading your code can see which packages they need.
The next time you begin an R session, you‚Äôll have to reload the package with library if you want to use it, but you won‚Äôt have to reinstall it. You only have to install each package once.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
section: 7.1 Creating and saving a small data set
text:
7.1 Creating and saving a small data set

Open Excel, LibreOffice Calc, Google Sheets or similar.
Create a tiny data set, for example:

Column 1:¬†student
Column 2:¬†score

Fill in a few rows with names and marks.
Save the file as¬†CSV (Comma-Separated Values)¬†and call it something like¬†ifp_scores.csv.
Make sure you save it inside your¬†IFP_Stats¬†project folder.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
7.2 Reading the CSV into R
In a new code chunk in your R Markdown file, or in a script, type:

library(tidyverse)

scores <- read_csv("ifp_scores.csv")

Rows: 5 Columns: 2
‚îÄ‚îÄ Column specification ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Delimiter: ","
chr (1): student
dbl (1): score

‚Ñπ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
‚Ñπ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

scores

# A tibble: 5 √ó 2
  student score
  <chr>   <dbl>
1 Ana        82
2 Sam        74
3 Jae        91
4 Luis       67
5 Mira       88


Helpful tip: if your cursor is between the quotation marks¬†" "¬†inside¬†read_csv("")¬†and you press¬†Tab, RStudio will show a list of files in your project so you can choose the correct name.
The object¬†scores¬†should now appear in the¬†Environment¬†pane. To see how many rows and columns there are, use:

dim(scores)

[1] 5 2


To see the structure of the data:

glimpse(scores)

Rows: 5
Columns: 2
$ student <chr> "Ana", "Sam", "Jae", "Luis", "Mira"
$ score   <dbl> 82, 74, 91, 67, 88

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
8.1 Start with a clean workspace

Go to¬†Tools > Global Options‚Ä¶.
Under¬†General, untick¬†‚ÄúRestore .RData into workspace at startup‚Äù.
Set¬†‚ÄúSave workspace to .RData on exit‚Äù¬†to¬†‚ÄúNever‚Äù.
Click¬†Apply¬†and¬†OK.

This means RStudio will start with an empty workspace each time, so you must re-run your scripts to recreate objects. This is good practice and avoids confusing ‚Äúleft-over‚Äù objects.

title: Getting Started with R and RStudio ‚Äì IFP
text:
8.2 Wrap long lines of code

Go to¬†Tools > Global Options‚Ä¶¬†again.
Click¬†Code¬†in the left-hand menu.
Tick¬†‚ÄúSoft-wrap R source files‚Äù.
Click¬†Apply¬†and¬†OK.

Now long lines of code will wrap inside the editor, so you do not have to scroll sideways.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
To produce short reports that combine code, output, and written explanation, we will use¬†R Markdown.¬†


Create a new R Markdown document via:
File > New File > R Markdown‚Ä¶
Give your document a title (e.g.¬†Intro Lab) and enter your name. Leave¬†HTML¬†as the default output format, then click¬†OK.
RStudio creates a template file. Delete everything¬†below the first code chunk¬†so that you begin with a clean document.


Insert a new R code chunk using either:

Insert > R, or
Ctrl + Alt + I¬†(Windows) /¬†Option + Cmd + I¬†(macOS)

Inside the chunk, type:

# Packages used in this document
library(tidyverse)

‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5
‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.5.2     ‚úî tibble    3.3.0
‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1
‚úî purrr     1.1.0     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Running the chunk may produce several informational messages ‚Äî this is normal.



Inside a code chunk,¬†#¬†creates a¬†comment¬†which R ignores. Use comments to explain what your code is doing.




Outside code chunks you can write ordinary text.
Headings are created using¬†#:
# R code examples
When the¬†.Rmd¬†file is rendered, this becomes a formatted heading.



Inside a code chunk:¬†#¬†creates a comment
Outside a code chunk:¬†#¬†creates a heading




Choose a few of the symbols below and, in your¬†.Rmd, write:

a short explanation of what each one does
an example inside a code chunk

Available symbols:
+
-
*
/
()
^
<-
<
>
<=
>=
==
!=
You might structure it like this:

# Addition
2 + 3

[1] 5






So far we have stored single numbers using <-, for example:
x <- 5
To store a sequence of numbers, combine them using the c() function.
A sequence of elements of the same type is called a vector.
For example:
myfirstvector <- c(1, 5, 3, 7)
myfirstvector
R prints:
[1] 1 5 3 7
You can carry out arithmetic on every element of the vector:
myfirstvector + 5
Returns:
[1] 6 10 8 12
Vectors can also contain words (‚Äúcharacter‚Äù data):
wordsvector <- c("cat", "dog", "parrot", "peppapig")
wordsvector
R prints:
[1] "cat" "dog" "parrot" "peppapig"
You may use single or double quotation marks; both work.
You can check the type of an object using class():
class(wordsvector)
Because addition only makes sense for numbers, R will give an error if you try an invalid operation:
wordsvector + 5
Finally, if you mix types inside c(), R converts everything to the most general type (usually characters):
mysecondvector <- c(4, "cat")
mysecondvector
Returns:
[1] "4" "cat"
Putting all of this together, you now know how R stores individual values, sequences of numbers, and sequences of text, and how R decides what type each vector should be. These tools form the foundation for reading, inspecting, and describing real datasets ‚Äî skills you will now begin applying in your coursework.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
Tutorial Format
At the start of each teaching block, you will receive a dataset that you will use throughout the tutorials for that block. By the end of each block, your group will produce a written report analysing the dataset.
Report deadlines:

Formative Report : 12 noon, Friday 2025

Reports must be submitted as PDF files (not .qmd or .Rmd source files). As these are group submissions, no extensions will be given.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
Group Setup
Work through tutorial tasks in groups of up to 5 students.

Each week, one person is the driver and the rest are navigators.

The driver types the code and edits the report template file.

The navigators read carefully, make suggestions, and help with debugging.

Rotate the driver each week so that everyone has a turn.

Driver:
Download the template report file below, upload it to your RStudio, and work in that file. Save regularly via File ‚Üí Save.
üëâ Download the Formative Report template (.Rmd)
Navigators:
Support the strategy, spot typos, and help troubleshoot.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
Report Format
Each report must follow these rules:

Submit a PDF no longer than 6 sides of A4 (excluding appendices).

Keep the default knitting settings (font, margins, spacing).

Appendices do not count towards the page limit.

You must include a compulsory appendix listing all R code used.

This is added automatically by including the following section at the very end of your .qmd file (already present in the template):

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
Lab Help and Support
The tutorials are designed with multiple layers of support. If you are unsure or stuck: Raise your hand for help from a tutor. Hover over the superscript numbers to view quick hints for commands and functions. Scroll to the Worked Example section at the bottom of the tutorial to see a parallel worked solution in R. Even if you complete the task without the Worked Example, make sure you read it carefully during independent study ‚Äî it is designed to reinforce the reasoning and R skills you will need for later weeks.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
1.1 Data
CollegeScores Dataset
You will work with the CollegeScores dataset in this tutorial.
At the link CollegeScores_teaching.csv you will find information about 400 higher-education institutions in the United States.
The dataset includes variables describing each institution‚Äôs location, sector (public/private), tuition costs, enrolment, and the demographic composition of their student body.
You will use this dataset throughout the Stats block for your formative report.
Below is a description of the variables included in the dataset.








Variable Name
Description




Name
Name of the institution


State
U.S. state where the institution is located


ID
Unique identifier for the institution


Main
Main campus indicator (1 = main campus, 0 = branch campus)


Control
Type of institution (Public, Private, For-profit)


Region
Geographical region in the U.S.


Locale
Setting of the institution (City, Suburb, Town, Rural)


Enrollment
Total undergraduate enrolment


PartTime
Percent of undergraduates who are part-time students


TuitionIn
In-state tuition and fees (USD)


TuitionOut
Out-of-state tuition and fees (USD)


White
Percent of undergraduates who identify as White


Black
Percent of undergraduates who identify as Black


Hispanic
Percent of undergraduates who identify as Hispanic


Asian
Percent of undergraduates who identify as Asian


Other
Percent of undergraduates who identify with another racial/ethnic group













Tip



When you write about the data in your report, you will describe variables in words, not as code. This table is your reference for names and meanings.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
1.2 Tasks
For Formative Report you will eventually complete several tasks.
This week we focus only on Task 1.


1) Read the CollegeScores dataset into R, inspect it, and write a concise introduction to the data and its structure.



Display and describe the categorical variables.




Display and describe a selection of numeric variables.




Display and describe at least one relationship between two or three variables.




Finish the report write-up, knit to PDF, and submit.



This tutorial is designed to help you complete Task 1.

1.3 Task 1, sub-tasks






Tip



Tip: Hover over the footnotes for hints showing useful R functions.


This week you only need to complete Task 1. The steps below are suggestions to guide your work.

Read the data into R (from the provided CSV file in datasets/) and give the object a sensible name (for example college).1
View the data in RStudio and check that it matches your expectations.2
How many rows (observations) are there in the dataset?3
How many columns (variables) are there?4
What type is each variable in R (character, numeric, factor, etc.)?5
Pick at least four variables (a mix of categorical and numeric). For each one:

State whether it is categorical or numeric.
State its level of measurement (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio).
Give one example value from the data.

For several numeric variables (e.g.¬†Enrollment, TuitionIn, TuitionOut), find the minimum, maximum, and mean values.6
Identify which variables contain missing values (if any) and how many.7
Write a short description of the dataset (one paragraph) for a generic reader. You might include:

What the data represent.
How many institutions and variables are included.
The kinds of information recorded (location, enrolment, costs, student characteristics).
A brief comment on any clear missing data issues.



You do not need to include R output in the report; you only need the written description. Keep this paragraph; you will re-use it in your report.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
2 Worked example
Consider the dataset provided in datasets/HollywoodMovies.csv, containing 1295 observations on the following 15 variables:








Variable Name
Description




Movie
Title of the movie


LeadStudio
Primary U.S. distributor


RottenTomatoes
Critics' rating (Rotten Tomatoes)


AudienceScore
Audience rating (Rotten Tomatoes)


Genre
Film genre (e.g., Action Adventure, Comedy, Thriller)


TheatersOpenWeek
Number of screens on opening weekend


OpeningWeekend
Opening weekend gross (in millions)


BOAvgOpenWeekend
Average box office income per theatre, opening weekend


Budget
Production budget (in millions)


DomesticGross
U.S. gross income (in millions)


ForeignGross
Foreign gross income (in millions)


WorldGross
Worldwide gross income (in millions)


Profitability
Worldwide gross as a percentage of budget


OpenProfit
Percentage of budget recovered on opening weekend


Year
Year of release







These data were compiled from Box Office Mojo, The Numbers, and Rotten Tomatoes.

We load the tidyverse package as we will use the functions
read_csv() and glimpse() from this package.


Load tidyverse and import the data

library(tidyverse)


read_csv() reads CSV (comma-separated values) files.
The loaded data are stored in an object called movies using the arrow <-.


movies <- read_csv("HollywoodMovies.csv")



Take a first look at the data

head() shows by default the first six rows of the dataset.
Use n = 10 to show more rows (e.g., head(movies, n = 10)).


head(movies)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 15
  Movie           LeadStudio RottenTomatoes AudienceScore Genre TheatersOpenWeek
  <chr>           <chr>               <dbl>         <dbl> <chr>            <dbl>
1 2016: Obama's ‚Ä¶ Rocky Mou‚Ä¶             26            73 Docu‚Ä¶                1
2 21 Jump Street  Sony Pict‚Ä¶             85            82 Come‚Ä¶             3121
3 A Late Quartet  Entertain‚Ä¶             76            71 Drama                9
4 A Royal Affair  Magnolia ‚Ä¶             90            82 Drama                7
5 Abraham Lincol‚Ä¶ Twentieth‚Ä¶             35            51 Horr‚Ä¶             3108
6 Act of Valor    Relativit‚Ä¶             27            72 Acti‚Ä¶             3039
# ‚Ñπ 9 more variables: OpeningWeekend <dbl>, BOAvgOpenWeekend <dbl>,
#   Budget <dbl>, DomesticGross <dbl>, WorldGross <dbl>, ForeignGross <dbl>,
#   Profitability <dbl>, OpenProfit <dbl>, Year <dbl>



dim() returns the dimensions of the dataset:
- number of rows (observations)
- number of columns (variables)


dim(movies)

[1] 1295   15



glimpse() provides a compact summary of the entire dataset.
It shows:
- the number of rows and columns
- each variable‚Äôs name
- its type (e.g., <dbl>, <chr>)
- a preview of the first few values
Useful for checking that variables are read correctly and spotting problems such as missing values. Ideal for large datasets.


glimpse(movies)

Rows: 1,295
Columns: 15
$ Movie            <chr> "2016: Obama's America", "21 Jump Street", "A Late Qu‚Ä¶
$ LeadStudio       <chr> "Rocky Mountain Pictures", "Sony Pictures Releasing",‚Ä¶
$ RottenTomatoes   <dbl> 26, 85, 76, 90, 35, 27, 91, 56, 11, 44, 93, 63, 87, 9‚Ä¶
$ AudienceScore    <dbl> 73, 82, 71, 82, 51, 72, 62, 47, 47, 63, 82, 51, 63, 9‚Ä¶
$ Genre            <chr> "Documentary", "Comedy", "Drama", "Drama", "Horror", ‚Ä¶
$ TheatersOpenWeek <dbl> 1, 3121, 9, 7, 3108, 3039, 132, 245, 2539, 3192, 3, 1‚Ä¶
$ OpeningWeekend   <dbl> 0.03, 36.30, 0.08, 0.04, 16.31, 24.48, 1.14, 0.70, 11‚Ä¶
$ BOAvgOpenWeekend <dbl> 30000, 11631, 8889, 5714, 5248, 8055, 8636, 2857, 449‚Ä¶
$ Budget           <dbl> 3.0, 42.0, NA, NA, 68.0, 12.0, NA, 7.5, 35.0, 50.0, 1‚Ä¶
$ DomesticGross    <dbl> 33.35, 138.45, 1.56, 1.55, 37.52, 70.01, 1.99, 3.01, ‚Ä¶
$ WorldGross       <dbl> 33.35, 202.81, 6.30, 7.60, 137.49, 82.50, 3.59, 8.54,‚Ä¶
$ ForeignGross     <dbl> 0.00, 64.36, 4.74, 6.05, 99.97, 12.49, 1.60, 5.53, 9.‚Ä¶
$ Profitability    <dbl> 1334.00, 482.88, NA, NA, 202.19, 687.50, NA, 113.87, ‚Ä¶
$ OpenProfit       <dbl> 1.20, 86.43, NA, NA, 23.99, 204.00, NA, 9.33, 32.57, ‚Ä¶
$ Year             <dbl> 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012, 2012,‚Ä¶








Example writeup



A dataset containing records for 1295 Hollywood films released between 2012 and 2018 was obtained from public film industry sources including Box Office Mojo, The Numbers, and Rotten Tomatoes. The dataset includes 15 variables describing key financial and categorical features of each film. Four variables are numeric, providing information such as production budget (in millions of dollars), domestic and foreign box office revenue, and worldwide gross. The remaining variables are categorical and describe aspects such as film genre, lead studio, and release year. Initial inspection shows considerable variation in budgets and earnings across films, and several missing values in variables such as Budget, ForeignGross, and Profitability. These data offer a useful basis for examining factors associated with box office performance.




Summary statistics

summary() produces quick descriptive statistics for each variable.
For numeric variables, it shows the minimum, maximum, median, mean, and quartiles.
For categorical variables, it shows frequency counts for each category.
Useful for a fast overview of the dataset.


summary(movies)

    Movie            LeadStudio        RottenTomatoes  AudienceScore  
 Length:1295        Length:1295        Min.   : 0.00   Min.   :10.00  
 Class :character   Class :character   1st Qu.:33.00   1st Qu.:49.00  
 Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Median :61.00   Median :64.00  
                                       Mean   :57.58   Mean   :62.18  
                                       3rd Qu.:84.00   3rd Qu.:77.00  
                                       Max.   :99.00   Max.   :99.00  
                                       NA's   :6                      
    Genre           TheatersOpenWeek OpeningWeekend    BOAvgOpenWeekend
 Length:1295        Min.   :   1.0   Min.   :  0.020   Min.   :   204  
 Class :character   1st Qu.: 152.5   1st Qu.:  0.845   1st Qu.:  3482  
 Mode  :character   Median :2459.0   Median :  7.600   Median :  6586  
                    Mean   :2008.0   Mean   : 17.541   Mean   : 13400  
                    3rd Qu.:3213.5   3rd Qu.: 20.810   3rd Qu.: 14534  
                    Max.   :4529.0   Max.   :257.700   Max.   :240000  
                                                                       
     Budget       DomesticGross      WorldGross       ForeignGross    
 Min.   :  0.90   Min.   :  1.02   Min.   :   0.74   Min.   :  -0.76

 Mean   : 51.38   Mean   : 58.16   Mean   : 147.01   Mean   :  88.84  
 3rd Qu.: 65.00   3rd Qu.: 66.44   3rd Qu.: 160.38   3rd Qu.:  89.75

 Profitability       OpenProfit           Year

 Max.   :10176.0   Max.   :3373.00   Max.   :2018  
 NA's   :239       NA's   :239                     


You probably will not understand every part of the summary output yet, and that is completely fine. For now, focus on the minimum, maximum, mean, and the general spread of the numeric variables.
For the categorical variables, the output is not very informative at the moment. These variables are stored as character data, but we can tell R to treat them as factors, which makes their behaviour clearer in later analysis.


Convert selected variables to factors

What does factor() do?
factor() is a function in R that turns a variable into a factor, which is R‚Äôs way of storing categorical data (groups, labels, categories).
Many datasets import text categories as "character" data.
Using factor() tells R that these values represent categories, not free-text.


movies$Genre <- factor(movies$Genre)
movies$LeadStudio <- factor(movies$LeadStudio)
movies$Year <- factor(movies$Year)

For example:

movies$Genre contains labels such as "Comedy", "Drama", "Horror".

factor(movies$Genre) converts these labels into a categorical variable.

We use:
movies$Genre <- factor(movies$Genre)
to replace the original column with a factor version of itself.
The $ operator

The $ symbol is used to select a single column from a dataset.
For example,
movies$Genre means ‚Äúthe Genre column inside the movies dataset‚Äù.


Check the updated structure:

After converting character variables into factors, the output of summary() becomes much more informative for categorical data.
Instead of only showing "Length", "Class", and "Mode", R now displays the number of observations in each category (for example, how many films belong to each genre or studio).
This is why converting categorical variables to factors is useful: it allows R to treat them properly as categories and summarise them in a meaningful way.


summary(movies)

    Movie                             LeadStudio  RottenTomatoes 
 Length:1295        Warner Bros.           :136   Min.   : 0.00  
 Class :character   Universal Pictures     :114   1st Qu.:33.00  
 Mode  :character   Lionsgate              :106   Median :61.00  
                    Twentieth Century Fox  :103   Mean   :57.58  
                    Paramount Pictures     : 76   3rd Qu.:84.00  
                    Sony Pictures Releasing: 72   Max.   :99.00

                  NA's   :239

 Mean   :  88.84   Mean   :  435.7   Mean   :  64.50   2015:190  
 3rd Qu.:  89.75   3rd Qu.:  483.0   3rd Qu.:  62.59   2016:196  
 Max.   :1369.54   Max.   :10176.0   Max.   :3373.00   2017:182  
                   NA's   :239       NA's   :239       2018:189  








How to read the summary output





How to read the summary output
The¬†summary()¬†function gives a quick statistical overview of every variable in the dataset. For¬†numeric variables, it shows:

Min.¬†‚Äì the smallest value
1st Qu.¬†‚Äì the value below which 25% of the data lie
Median¬†‚Äì the middle value
Mean¬†‚Äì the average
3rd Qu.¬†‚Äì the value below which 75% of the data lie
Max.¬†‚Äì the largest value
NA‚Äôs¬†‚Äì how many values are missing

These numbers help you understand the overall range and spread of each variable. For example,
¬†Budget¬†ranges from¬†0.9 to 365 million dollars, and
¬†RottenTomatoes¬†scores run from¬†0 to 99.
For¬†categorical variables‚Äînow stored as factors‚Äîsuch as¬†Genre¬†or¬†LeadStudio, the summary shows the¬†number of observations in each category. This lets us quickly see which genres or studios appear most often in the dataset.
It is also helpful to check whether the¬†minimum or maximum values look realistic. For instance, the¬†Profitability¬†variable has a¬†maximum of 10176%, meaning a film supposedly earned more than one hundred times its budget. This is unusually high and suggests there may be some data entry errors that need to be investigated later.
Overall,¬†summary()¬†provides a useful first look at the structure of the dataset and can help identify potential issues such as unrealistic values or many missing entries.





Detecting unusual values
Sometimes it is helpful to look for values that seem unrealistic.
From the summary output, we noticed that¬†Profitability¬†has a maximum value of¬†10,176%, which suggests a film supposedly earned more than¬†one hundred times¬†its budget. This is extremely unlikely and probably indicates a data entry error.
To inspect these cases more closely, we can filter the rows where profitability is greater than 1000%:

a > b tests whether a is greater than b. a < b tests whether a is smaller than b. a == b tests whether a is equal to b; notice the double equal sign! You can also use >= or <=


movies[movies$Profitability > 1000, ]

# A tibble: 319 √ó 15
   Movie          LeadStudio RottenTomatoes AudienceScore Genre TheatersOpenWeek
   <chr>          <fct>               <dbl>         <dbl> <fct>            <dbl>
 1 2016: Obama's‚Ä¶ Rocky Mou‚Ä¶             26            73 Docu‚Ä¶                1
 2 <NA>           <NA>                   NA            NA <NA>                NA
 3 <NA>           <NA>                   NA            NA <NA>                NA
 4 <NA>           <NA>                   NA            NA <NA>                NA
 5 Beasts of the‚Ä¶ Fox Searc‚Ä¶             86            76 Drama                4
 6 Chernobyl Dia‚Ä¶ Warner Br‚Ä¶             19            29 Horr‚Ä¶             2433
 7 Chronicle      Twentieth‚Ä¶             85            71 Thri‚Ä¶             2907
 8 <NA>           <NA>                   NA            NA <NA>                NA
 9 <NA>           <NA>                   NA            NA <NA>                NA
10 <NA>           <NA>                   NA            NA <NA>                NA
# ‚Ñπ 309 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 9 more variables: OpeningWeekend <dbl>, BOAvgOpenWeekend <dbl>,
#   Budget <dbl>, DomesticGross <dbl>, WorldGross <dbl>, ForeignGross <dbl>,
#   Profitability <dbl>, OpenProfit <dbl>, Year <fct>


If we decide that these values are not plausible, we can replace them with¬†NA¬†so they do not distort later analyses:

movies$Profitability[movies$Profitability > 1000] <- NA



Inspecting the cleaned variable

summary(movies$Profitability)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
    2.3   132.0   246.8   302.6   415.3   993.3     319 


This output now shows:

a much lower and more realistic maximum (now around 993%)
an updated mean and median
the number of NA values introduced (319), matching the number we replaced

This check reassures us that the cleaning step worked as expected and reassures us that the values remaining in the dataset are plausible for later analysis.
To check the range more directly, we can examine the minimum and maximum values while ignoring missing data:

min(movies$Profitability, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 2.3

max(movies$Profitability, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 993.33








What to do with NAs afterwards?






It is normal for real datasets to contain missing values.
Many functions (e.g.,¬†min(),¬†mean()) require¬†na.rm = TRUE¬†to ignore them.
More advanced handling (e.g., imputation) comes¬†much later¬†in the course.

For now, the key idea is simply:
‚ÄúWe remove impossible values so that the dataset provides sensible summaries.‚Äù









What else should we examine?





Here are additional checks that match the psychology approach:

2. Check for impossible or negative values
In your dataset, some variables show impossible values:

ForeignGross¬†has a minimum of¬†‚Äì0.76 million¬†‚Üí negative earnings are impossible
OpeningWeekend¬†has a minimum close to zero (fine), but some extremely large values
BOAvgOpenWeekend¬†has a maximum of¬†240,000, which seems unusually high for average per-screen income

We can inspect suspicious values:

movies[movies$ForeignGross < 0, ]

# A tibble: 6 √ó 15
  Movie           LeadStudio RottenTomatoes AudienceScore Genre TheatersOpenWeek
  <chr>           <fct>               <dbl>         <dbl> <fct>            <dbl>
1 The Christmas ‚Ä¶ EchoLight‚Ä¶             21            75 Adve‚Ä¶                5
2 90 Minutes in ‚Ä¶ The Samue‚Ä¶             24            50 Drama              878
3 Popstar: Never‚Ä¶ Universal‚Ä¶             78            65 Come‚Ä¶             2311
4 Lowriders       BH Tilt                57            61 Drama              295
5 Sleight         BH Tilt                77            52 Acti‚Ä¶              565
6 The Square      Magnolia ‚Ä¶             85            70 Drama                4
# ‚Ñπ 9 more variables: OpeningWeekend <dbl>, BOAvgOpenWeekend <dbl>,
#   Budget <dbl>, DomesticGross <dbl>, WorldGross <dbl>, ForeignGross <dbl>,
#   Profitability <dbl>, OpenProfit <dbl>, Year <fct>


Then correct:

movies$ForeignGross[movies$ForeignGross < 0] <- NA



3. Explore missing values
The summary shows many variables with¬†239 missing values¬†(Budget, Profitability, OpenProfit).
Add a short explanation:

Some films have missing financial information‚Äîthis is common in movie datasets.
We keep missing values as¬†NA¬†and handle them later during analysis using functions such as¬†mean(..., na.rm = TRUE).

You can also look at a full missing-data overview:

colSums(is.na(movies))

           Movie       LeadStudio   RottenTomatoes    AudienceScore 
               0                0                6                0 
           Genre TheatersOpenWeek   OpeningWeekend BOAvgOpenWeekend 
               0                0                0                0 
          Budget    DomesticGross       WorldGross     ForeignGross 
             239                0                0                6 
   Profitability       OpenProfit             Year 
             319              239                0 








Cleaning explaination paragraph



After inspecting the summary output, we noticed that some values were unrealistic, particularly in the¬†Profitabilityvariable, which included cases above 10,000%. Since such values imply a film earned more than one hundred times its budget, they are likely due to data entry errors. We therefore identified all films with¬†Profitability¬†greater than 1000% and replaced these values with¬†NA¬†so they would not distort later analyses. We also checked for other implausible values, such as negative¬†ForeignGross, and handled these similarly. Missing values remain coded as¬†NA, and functions such as¬†mean(),¬†min(), and¬†max()¬†will require the argument¬†na.rm = TRUE¬†to return a numeric result. Re-running¬†summary(movies)¬†now provides a more realistic overview of the dataset.






After checking for impossible values, correcting clear errors, and converting categorical variables to factors, we now have a cleaner and more reliable dataset. At this stage, the aim is simply to¬†ensure the data make sense¬†before moving on to later analytical tasks.

summary(movies)

This allows you to confirm:

the categorical variables now display meaningful counts for each category
extremely large or impossible values have been removed
missing values remain coded as NA (ready to be handled properly in later weeks)
the numeric summaries (min, max, mean) now fall within sensible ranges

At this point, the dataset is in a good condition for basic exploration.
Now, we have enough information to write a clear introductory paragraph describing the dataset






Example writeup



A dataset containing records for 1295 Hollywood films released between 2012 and 2018 was analysed. The dataset includes financial information such as production budget, opening weekend gross, domestic revenue, and worldwide revenue, as well as critics‚Äô and audience ratings. Additional variables include film genre, lead studio, and release year. Initial inspection indicated wide variability in budgets and earnings, and some missing values in foreign gross and profitability measures. These data provide a useful foundation for investigating predictors of film success.

title: Research Design & Data ‚Äì MSDA IFP
text:
3. Student Glossary
To conclude the lab, create a¬†glossary of R functions.
Use Word, Excel, OneNote, or any tool you like, and make a simple table with two columns:

Function name
Brief description of what the function does

This ‚Äúdo it yourself‚Äù glossary will help you revise the key ideas from today‚Äôs lab and will be extremely useful when completing the weekly quizzes.
Below is a starter example you can expand:







Function
Use and package




read_csv
Reads comma-separated value files. Part of the¬†tidyverse.


View
Opens a spreadsheet-style view of a dataset.


head
Shows the first few rows (six by default).


nrow
Returns the number of rows in a dataset.


ncol
Returns the number of columns in a dataset.


dim
Returns both rows and columns (dimensions).


glimpse
Provides a compact overview of all variables (dplyr).


str
Shows the internal structure of an object.


summary
Gives summary statistics for each variable.


factor
Converts a variable into a categorical factor.



Feel free to add more as you encounter additional functions during the course.


Reference
Lock, Robin H, Patti Frazer Lock, Kari Lock Morgan, Eric F. Lock, and Dennis F. Lock. 2020.¬†Statistics: Unlocking the Power of Data. John Wiley & Sons.
